author: Richard Hartley-Parkinson
title: Wag man returns and he’s coming for your kids
text:
The ‘wag man’ is being reintroduced to crack down on turancy (Picture: Getty) The ‘wag man’, better known as the school truancy officer, is being reintroduced to crack down on children skipping classes on Merseyside.
Years since the scourge of school truants pounded the streets rounding up youngsters, a new drive in Liverpool will see the reintroduction of patrols by council staff and police as part of crackdown in the city.
They will also tackle parents who keep their children off school without good reason.
Child 'forced to eat hamster food and beaten daily by his mother' In Liverpool, primary schools 11.33 per cent of pupils are persistently absent compared with 8.8 per cent nationally, while at secondary school level it is 17.15 per cent compared with 12.3 per cent across the rest of the country.
Mayor of Liverpool Joe Anderson said: ‘A considerable amount of excellent work to support children’s attendance at school has been done in Liverpool, but as a city we are still lagging behind other core cities and the national average.
‘As a parent and grandparent, I want to see every part of our education system working well for the children, and as mayor of Liverpool I want to make sure they are ready to face the best possible life chances in a city that is full of opportunities.
Woman who poured 96% sulphuric acid on sleeping partner is jailed for life ‘We need to build on existing good practice and introduce new measures to help tackle the issues facing Liverpool in relation to unacceptably high absence rates.’
Local businesses are also being encouraged to get involved.
Figures from the city council say a child who is 10 minutes’ late misses 32 hours a year of lost education and missing one day a week loses two months a year of education – while half a day a week missed throughout school life equates to one full year of lost education.
